> The characters act like they would in Everlasting Summer (Retain original personality)

Cons:
> Short story
> Plot can be slightly predictable at times
> Translation is not the best at times
> Can't decompile the actual game (Can't root around for the music or the artwork in the directory)


Final Verdect: 9/10
Not as good as the original game but you can tell some time and effort was put into making this game faithful to it as possible (Soviet Games would be proud). It's short but you will love every moment you play it (If you love visual novels).

GO PLAY IT!

reviewText:
Product received for free

I definitely recommend Frosty Kiss to anyone that enjoyed their experiences in Everlasting Summer. Frosty Kiss is filled with small things that make your memories from Everlasting Summer come back; memories of those blissful days in Sovynok when everything was so simple, yet so complicated. And most importantly memories of our journies with these star-crossed strangers that we grew to love (possible pun intended there), and the memorable moments we went through with them as we began to strive less and less to find that cursed bus and more and more to just get them to accept us.
I love all the little references to the events in Sovynok and how the characters have grown as individuals, as well as a group that can share such a great treasure together. The music adds to that atmosphere and offers a laid-back vibe and the tone of every character pleasantly gives the suggestion that there will always be something to look forward to in life.

On a side note, despite going through each route I never unlocked any of the four achievements for the game. And they are all hidden achievements so I don't know what to do to unlock them. Other than that it's a very nice and simple game, certainly fulfilling, with no mazes or Yulya's coincidentally gathering supplies for the winter. (And regrettably no stargazing even though that was always a thing with Lena)
